organizations.name: credit doug mills/the new york times

text: Continue reading the main story Photo Bill Belichick, Tom Brady and LeGarrette Blount celebrate after the New England Patriots’ victory. Credit Doug Mills/The New York Times HOUSTON — The whole time Robert Alford was dashing down the sideline, ball in hand, yards away from scoring on the interception return that would extend his Atlanta Falcons’ lead to 21-0 over New England in the second quarter of Sunday’s Super Bowl , all I kept thinking — and I might have said it aloud, too — was, “This is actually going to happen. The Falcons are going to win.” The Falcons were going to win. But the Falcons didn’t win. You probably know this by now. It was one of the most devastating collapses in professional sports history — or one of the greatest comebacks, depending on your perspective. It was either, or both, but certainly not neither. The New England Patriots won the Super Bowl, 34-28, in overtime, overcoming a 25-point third-quarter deficit. In the process, they ruined many a well-crafted story touting the mighty Falcons and their first championship since beginning play in 1966.
